    Key Concepts ğŸ”‘

    • Repository (Repo): This is your projectâ€™s folder. It contains all of your projectâ€™s files and stores each fileâ€™s revision history. Your zeural1.github.io repository is a great example!
    • Commit: A commit is like a snapshot of your project at a specific point in time. When you make a change and commit it, youâ€™re saving a new version of your work. ğŸ’¾
    • Branch: A branch is a parallel version of your repository. You can create branches to work on new features without affecting the main version of your project (often called the main branch). ğŸŒ¿
    • Pull Request (PR): When youâ€™re ready to merge your changes from a branch into the main project, you open a pull request. This allows others to review your changes before theyâ€™re added to the main codebase. Itâ€™s a great way to collaborate and get feedback. ğŸ’¬
    • Git: Git is the version control system that GitHub is built on. Itâ€™s a command-line tool that you can use to interact with your local and remote repositories.

    Why use GitHub? ğŸ’¡

    • Collaboration: GitHub makes it easy to work with others on projects, whether theyâ€™re your friends, colleagues, or open-source contributors from around the world. ğŸŒ
    • Version Control: Never worry about losing your work or messing up your code again! With GitHub, you can always revert to a previous version of your project.
